field_edited_text.value:
V. Preliminary Planning

Preliminary planning concepts were developed
at the earliest possible stage to enable
merchants and city officials to discuss various
alternatives for making improvements.

Preliminary concepts were based on an analysis
of the findings of the research phase. These
findings dealt with socio-economic
characteristics, existing physical relationships,
existing and proposed city programs an
environmental problems in the three areas.

For clarity and ease of understanding during
discussions with the various groups involved,
the findings of the study at this stage and the
implications drawn from them were
summarized in tabular form, grouped according
to the four categories shown above, and, with
the exception of socio-economic characteristics,
were also depicted graphically.

The findings and implications for each area are
summarized on the following pages:

1. Pennsylvania Avenue Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

The implication drawn from the finding that
the trade area population is almost totally
Black was that specialized treatment would be
required for the retail core, taking into account
the types of merchandise required and the
concentration of a population that has
relatively low income levels.

The high vacancy rates and declining
population indicated a need to consolidate
retail and service facilities and to either reduce
retail floor space or increase the shopping area’s
drawing power by carrying out dramatic
improvements.

Pennsylvania Avenue has a strong retail core in
the sector of the public market, while the
weaker areas further away have suffered from
increasing dilapidation.

b. Existing Physical Relationships

A major implication in this category deals with
the need to avoid improvement programs that
would reduce the area’s population still further
by removing the multi-family dwellings that are
predominant without replacing them with other
types of housing.

The north-south street pattern, which serves as

a link between the central business district and
outer areas, is a prime cause of congestion,
indicating a need for an alternative route for
such traffic. The length of the commercial strip
development also indicates problems in
providing adequate off-street parking.

c. Present City Program and Proposals

These include intensive rehabilitation under the
Community Renewal Plan, additions to several
public housing projects and a major freeway
system, all of which will have a tendency to
reduce the trade area population and therefore
the potential for retail sales. In addition, a
proposed rapid transit line proposed for a
location a considerable distance away would
tend to pull shoppers away from Pennsylvania
Avenue.

The effect of other public programs of reducing
the population could be offset if housing
densities were increased in an extensive urban
renewal program proposed for the lower end of
Pennsylvania Avenue.

d. Environmental Problems

These dealt with the high incidence of
substandard and deficient buildings, traffic,
accumulation of junk and trash, the large
number of narrow lots and consequently
narrow stores and the extensive use of buildings
for both retailing and residential purposes.

These findings indicated that extensive
rehabilitation was unrealistic because of the
high cost, and that with a consolidation of the
retail core, the commercially deteriorated part
of the linear strip could be used for
high-density residential buildings. The findings
also indicated that through traffic should be
rerouted.

2. Light Street Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

A declining population, relatively high
unemployment rates and an increasing number
of low-income Black people in the area is
reducing purchasing power and causing
conflicting demands for goods and services.

Despite a low vacancy rate, property values are
dropping and improvements are not being
made, indicating a declining position for the
area as a retail shopping center. Ways must be
found of strengthening the position of the

shopping area, including improving the |5qb|ic
market.

b. Existing Physical Relationships

The trade area is essentially an enclave of
owner-occupied row houses surrounded by
industrial and wholesale activities. This will
limit expansion of the trade area unless housing
density is increased.

The location of the area has made it a corridor
for north-south traffic which has had an adverse
effect, and an east-west orientation seems
desirable to conteract this effect. Existing
physical relationships are shown in graphic
form.

c. Present City Programs and Proposals

These include a major urban renewal project to
the north, a major east-west expressway,
extensive conservation and clearance programs
in adjacent areas and a proposal to intensify
industrial development in the area.

These proposals could have a beneficial effect if
full consideration is given to the area’s
potential. Otherwise, the area may increasingly
become an isolated community surrounded by
activities that do not benefit the shopping
center or make use of its potentialities.

d. Environmental Problems

The extensive pockets of decay, both structural
and functional, in the area provide prime
targets for improvements that'would reduce the
size of the commercial core and make it more
compact.

Because of Light Street’s importance as a
business street, traffic congestion should be
eliminated by diverting through traffic to
surrounding arterial roads. Trucks should be
discouraged from using the streets in the area,
possibly by improving alleyways and making
them suitable for loading and unloading.

3. Monument Street Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

A relatively stable population, average incomes
and low vacancy rates compared to the other
areas give Monument Street a brighter future.
There is a need to reduce the amount of retail
floor space available, concentrating on the core
shopping area.
